input: What is the her2-neu gene?
__expected: factuality:The HER-2/neu gene is a member of the erbB-like oncogene family and is related to, but distinct from, the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). The gene is significant in the context of breast cancer.

__expected: icontains-all:her-2/neu, gene, breast, cancer

input: Summarize this article in plain language
__expected: factuality:The article discusses the HER-2/neu oncogene. Researchers studied this gene in 189 cases of breast cancer and found that it was often amplified, meaning there were higher amounts of it in the tumors. This means that the HER-2/neu gene could be used to predict if breast cancer will get significantly worse.

input: Summarize this article in plain language
__expected: icontains-all:her-2/neu, predict, breast, cancer

input: What are the most important takeaways from this article?
__expected: factuality:Alterations of the HER-2/neu gene were investigated in 189 primary human breast cancers, where it was found to be amplified in 30% of the tumors. Amplification of the HER-2/neu gene is a significant predictor of overall survival and time to relapse in breast cancer patients. The significance of HER-2/neu amplification as a prognostic factor remains even after accounting for other known prognostic factors. HER-2/neu amplification offers greater prognostic value than most currently used prognostic factors, including hormonal-receptor status, particularly in lymph node-positive breast cancer.

input: What are the most important takeaways from this article?
__expected: icontains-all:amplified, survival, time to relapse

input: What is the relationship between the HER-2/neu gene and the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)?
__expected: factuality:The HER-2/neu gene is closely related to, the EGFR gene. Both genes belong to the tyrosine kinase family, but HER-2/neu is located on chromosome 17, whereas EGFR is located on chromosome 7.
